Chapter:
Graph constructors
In this chapter we give functions which return various graphs found in the literature.
Vertex naming and automorphisms
The &AGT; package is designed to investigate and manipulate graphs in &Grape; format. When graphs are constructed in this format, useful information on the structure and properties of the graph is stored as record entries. Here, we describe how two of these entries are constructed by functions in the &AGT; package: the vertex names and group of automorphisms entries.
For many of the constructors found in this chapter, there is an optional argument which affects the information used and stored in the graph it constructs. Here, we list these options and describe how they affect the resulting graph.
<#Include Label="NoVertexNames">
<#Include Label="FullAutomorphismGroup">

This will make function entries less convoluted.
General constructions
In this section, we introduce functions which construct graphs that have well-known and general definitions. These include graphs constructed from graph operations like taking products, joins, bipartite doubles and antipodal quotients.
<#Include Label="AdjFunGraph">
<#Include Label="ProductGraph">
<#Include Label="PowerGraph">
<#Include Label="BoxProductGraph">
<#Include Label="BoxPowerGraph">
<#Include Label="CrossProductGraph">
<#Include Label="CrossPowerGraph">
<#Include Label="StrongProductGraph">
<#Include Label="StrongPowerGraph">
<#Include Label="GraphJoin">
<#Include Label="BipartiteDoubleGraph">
<#Include Label="ExtendedBipartiteDoubleGraph">
<#Include Label="HalvedGraph">
<#Include Label="AntipodalQuotientGraph">
<#Include Label="SubspaceGraph">
<#Include Label="CliqueGraph">
<#Include Label="AGT_IncidenceGraph">
Basic constructions
In this section, we introduce functions which construct graphs that have relatively well-known and simple definitions. These include complete multipartite, Paley and Latin square graphs.
<#Include Label="CompleteMultipartiteGraph2">
<#Include Label="CycleGraph">
<#Include Label="CocktailPartyGraph">
<#Include Label="PaleyGraph">
<#Include Label="LatinSquareGraph">
<#Include Label="CompleteTaylorGraph">
<#Include Label="HaarGraph">
Subset constructions
In this section, each function constructs a graph for which each vertex is a subset of a finite set (for example, the Kneser and Odd graphs).
<#Include Label="KneserGraph">
<#Include Label="OddGraph">
<#Include Label="DoubledOddGraph">
<#Include Label="FoldedJohnsonGraph">
<#Include Label="ChangGraph">
Vector constructions
In this section, each function constructs a graph for which each vertex is a vector lying in a finite vector space (for example, the Hamming and Affine polar graphs).
<#Include Label="HammingGraph2">
<#Include Label="HypercubeGraph">
<#Include Label="DoobGraph">
<#Include Label="HalvedCubeGraph">
<#Include Label="FoldedCubeGraph">
<#Include Label="FoldedHalvedCubeGraph">
<#Include Label="BrouwerGraph">
<#Include Label="PasechnikGraph">
<#Include Label="AdditiveSymplecticCoverGraph">
<#Include Label="MultiplicativeSymplecticCoverGraph">
<#Include Label="AffinePolarGraphVO">
<#Include Label="AffinePolarGraphVNO">
Bilinear form constructions
In this section, each function constructs a graph for which each vertex is a matrix defined over a finite field, and considered as certain sesuilinear forms.
<#Include Label="BilinearFormsGraph">
<#Include Label="HermiteanFormsGraph">
Subspace constructions
In this section, each function constructs a graph for which each vertex is a subspace in a finite vector space (for example, the Grassmann and Polar graphs).

<#Include Label="DoubledGrassmannGraph">
